ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Modal logic, both in the area of logic and its philosophical implication.
I learned what modal logic is, the rules of different modal systems, and the controversies in modal logic

I learned about the different formal systems of modal logic, their relationship to semantic notions like transitivity, and the ongoing debates in the literature. It really improved my understanding of necessity and possibility.

I discovered the topic of modal logic, thinking of different possible worlds, the syntax and semantics of necessity and possibility, the problems that some philosophers have with modal logic. 

The problem sets in this class helped me develop my logical reasoning through proofs and my essay helped me think more critically of different philosophers' views on modal logic.
propositional modal logic, quantified modal logic, Quine
I learned the syntax and semantics of various modal logics.

A greater appreciation for how nebulous concepts such as necessity or possibility can be formalized as part of a system, which can in turn be used to derive new insights, or make us question the system itself/our intuitions.
Modal systems, diagrammatic method, quantified modal logic, soundness and completeness of PML.
I learned a lot about the formal systems of modal logic and the philosophy of language that applies to modal logic.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: 
Prof Shin is very nice. The handouts are detailed and easy-to-follow
Some suggestions: 
Maybe match the handouts to the ones that the professor uses during the lecture. 
I feel the workload is a bit low, maybe the course can be more rigorous and focused.

strengths: Prof Shin is absolutely amazing, and I would encourage anyone interested in logic to take one of her classes, the course is organized well, it is easy to ask questions during class for clarification 
weaknesses: none that I can think of
This course's strengths were its teaching and the material covered. The problem sets were also very helpful for learning the material.

Strengths: excellent lecture notes provided, clarity of explanations by the professor, topics well organized and well ordered throughout the semester (smooth transition from one topic to another)

Weaknesses: the workload was very light at the beginning of the semester and near the end there were more problem sets close together as well as our final paper. I would have appreciated if the workload would have been distributed more equally.
Professor Shin's notes are wonderful as usual, clear and efficient. The class was more of a lecture than a seminar, which I thought was effective for the material

I think too much focus was on the formal rules and syntax of modal logic rather than it's philosophical implications and controversies. As a result, we didn't have much preparation for the final paper.
The teaching was great! Assignment and project deadlines felt slightly ad-hoc and rushed.

The course was excellent, yet challenging. First off, the professor is very kind and treats the material with very great care. The course was well-organized and carefully structured, though it seemed more to be a lecture than a seminar at times (though this was not bad in and of itself--I very much liked this format). The workload was moderate and fair: there were five problem sets over the course of the semester, which I thought worked well for the course; a reading response; and a final paper. 

However, I wish that there was a textbook for this class. I also wish we did more examples in class or at the least, had additional examples uploaded to Canvas that students could go over and build intuition before doing the problem sets. In addition, I wish that answer keys were uploaded for the problem sets.
The course is well-organized for learning. Prof. Shin explains concepts very clearly and the lecture notes are clear.
This is a well-organized and well-taught course. The lectures were somewhat difficult to follow, but I think this is mostly due to COVID virtual learning.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The problem sets might have been easier if the lectures were recorded.

Handing out lecture notes was really helpful to come prepared and keep up in class. 

Despite the class being a seminar, there was very little time for student interaction and discussion on Zoom.
It didn't feel much different from an in-person lecture.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This is a good choice to fulfill both the logic and seminar requirements.

I would highly recommend this class to anyone interested in logic.  I found it very fun to think about statements about possibility and necessity since they are ubiquitous in our lives and create interesting issues in formal logic.

This is an amazing course. Professor Shin does a great job going over different formal systems of modal logic, their relationship to semantic notions like transitivity, and the ongoing debates in the literature. She also is just an amazing instructor.

I would recommend this class to any student interested in logic and would suggest they take mathematical logic prior to this course. There are a lot of basic topics that are covered in mathematical logic that we very briefly went over in order to understand modal logic and it would be helpful for students to have a deeper understanding of these topics prior to taking this class.
Yes, modal logic is fun!
Yes if you really like logic proofs.

This is an obscure topic that probably has very little practical application, but is definitely interesting if you like thinking about logic and its limitations or interaction with the real world. The workload is not too bad if you're already familiar with first order logic.

Yes, the course material is fascinating and the professor is great. However, I would recommend that students take this course after taking another lower-level logic course at Yale. That isn't required, I don't think, but will help with building intuition and foundation for some of the concepts we cover in modal logic.
Would definitely recommend any course with Prof. Shin!
I would certainly recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in philosophical logic.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar.
N/A
